ratings.comment: He explains idea clearly. However, this does not mean that his class is easy. In fact, his math522 relies heavily on algebra tricks and skills, and you also need high maturity in coming up with various ways( or even tricks) to prove some very abstract theorem in homework. What is even worse is that he is not willing to help.

Only 3 weeks into it and probably the best math class I've had. Andrej explains stuff extremely well. Made me realize how much more I need to learn when he tells us to get our hands dirty and prove something simple looking. I hear his exams are hard too.
Andrej is an international math olympiad from 1994. nuff said

Honestly the worst. He's REALLY smart and qualified to do mathematics, but the same does not apply to his ability to teach it.  Spent calculus lecture doing proofs not accessible to first-year students. I understood and got by solely because of my TA and many students weren't so lucky. The weekly discussion quiz got old real quick.

Very difficult.  Expected students to know way more coming in to the class than it seemed like most of them did. He did not tell the students what they were supposed to know he just assumed they knew it from previous classes.

Had taken BC calc in highschool and thought I would therefore be better off coming into this class... not the case. He makes the material seemingly much more difficult and wordy than need be. Wrote the text book so it's just as unhelpful. Lectures only make you more confused and lost.

Zlatos is clearly too clever to be teaching Calc 1. Glosses over concepts like they're common sense, mumbles when speaking, and asks "Any questions?" without looking at the students. High expectations, difficult exam. TAs very varied in quality. You need to work very hard by yourself if he's your professor.

The class is much harder than high school math. Exams were difficult but the curve was forgiving. He was quite helpful answering questions during and after lecture. I don't understand the negative reviews, he did explanations not proofs. It took time away from examples but it helped me.

Worst teacher I've ever had (if you can even call him that). Lectures were an hour and 15 minutes of proof after proof that really didn't help with the course material whatsoever. Exams are impossible and are nothing like the homework. FIND A DIFFERENT PROFESSOR

Terrible professor. The "textbook" (a poor composition of dated proofs from the mid 70s) was basically useless. Lectures revolved around him spewing out proofs. Exams contain only most difficult problems he can create. His english isn't bad,  he just not a good teacher by any means. I recommend finding a different professor.

WORST PROFESSOR EVER!! Expects you to know way too much for 221, is cocky at times, and while he asks if anyone has questions he never takes the time to look around and see hands in the air! Horrible at his job, at least in Math 221. The math department created their OWN textbook this semester, and it is horribly constructed, leaving you lost.

Awful professor for this class, I don't know how else to put it. Textbook was unhelpful and extremely difficult to understand. Lectures were boring and unnecessary, learned next to nothing in them. He talked over our heads, a terrible professor for freshman. He taught like we were seniors in an upper level math course. My TA even agrees with me.

This professor teaches this class a lot more complex than it needs to be. I understood AP calc pretty well in high school but this is MUCH harder. The material I understand, I only understand because I remember it from high school. The textbook is almost impossible to understand so I would suggest using youtube videos or another textbook instead

If you take this class, you're going to have a bad time. I only have any slight clue what's going on because of my background knowledge from high school calculus and I still struggle a lot. Finals are a lot harder than homework and examples and he is teaching this class way harder than it needs to be. You're going to have a bad time

This is historically a horrible class, especially when it comes to difficulty, no matter who teaches it.  That being said, Zlatos is a bad professor who focuses more on proofs than examples and often covers material in class that is way over his students heads.  It is very hard to receive a good grade in this class.

Do not take this class with Zlatos. Even if it was concepts I was familiar with from AP Calc, I'd have no idea what he was talking about. His exams are ridiculous, and he is not great at explaining things. I learned from my TA alone. Zlatos is awful. I've always enjoyed math and took calc previously, but still got nothing from his lectures.

Zlatos is down right awful and extremely difficult! Not helpful in office hours. Test are SUPER HARD and nothing like the easy online H.W!  Math 221 is a hard class at Madison. My advice, pick a professor with a lot of old practice exams available online. Buy a separate textbook if you can afford it. The PDF textbook they want your to is terrible.

Zlatos is god awful. He is funny sometimes, but can't explain anything for his life. Hope to the lords that you have a magnificent TA (unlike me) or you will fail regardless of whether you've taken calc in high school or not. Plus the lack of a REAL textbook is stupid.
The WORST math class I have ever taken. The level of difficultly was ridiculous. He is very knowledgable but is far too challenging.
Zlatos is the man! Gotta love this guy. Excellent teacher, nice guy

Extemely difficult. He recently reformated this class and had a specific exam for "making only the best students stand out." He is very boring and dry. He really knows what he is talking about, but very difficult. Homework is completely different than exams, so expect to be very confused during exams.

Talks way too quiet to sit in the back rows.  Homeworks are generally pretty easy.  Stupid how they only grade 3 problems when each assignment is between 15 and 20 problems.  Tests are relatively easy if you do the homework problems.  If you have a good TA class is a lot easier.

Great teacher. He is very devoted and passionate and does a great job in connecting math to reality. Exams are fair and attendance/notes is crucial.Course is applied pde's and feels like continuing 319 (321 isn't necessary). Physics background would make this class more interesting on the practical side but you don't need it, I did well without it.
He is really good.

This class is incredibly easy. I skipped class for two months and still got an A. I enjoyed lecture when attended since Andrej is a good teacher. He asks more difficult questions on exams, but he prepares you for it in lecture and doesn't try to trick you. Also, there is no homework and one of the tests is dropped. He is fair and a good professor.

This class is not too hard.  Just go to class and do the problems in the book until you clearly understand them well.  Also, try any practice exam problems he might give you.  I hate math, didn't go to discussions, and I got an A.  As long as you know you understand the material by doing problems out of the book you should do fine.

Lectures with examples followed by a solution.  One review session per exam which goes over old exams.  TA's are hard to understand, as is he if you're in the back.  Lectures on new concepts in the lecture before the test, does not review.  His exams are usually 7 problems totaling 70 points, 4 exams, 1 final, one dropped exam.  Good luck!
Gives really helpful examples and explains material really well.

Tests aren't extremely hard, and each one is curved quite well.  Go to lectures and discussion sections and you should be fine.  For cumulative final we got a sheet of paper for formulas etc that we could make up.

Helpful Professor and teach examples clearly.However he tends to make simple things look difficult by relying too much on the definition.Definitely has got to learn to use numbers more appropriately and teach students in the most simplest way. A great professor though.

Great professor.  Has high expectations, but has clear examples and concise homework assignments which closely resemble exams.  Zlatos has a great sense of humor, and uses it to keep the material interesting.

Not that hard. Teaching style a bit lengthy/confusing, but TA's and discussions are very helpful if you feel lost. No notecards allowed for tests, which was a bit hard as far as formulas. Final is cumulative, you get both sides of 8X11 for notes. Minor language barriers and fast pace.
